comment_text: Getting this done must be a great way of facing your fear of pain... i guess? The eye area is so sensitive and having it clamped  would feel so uncomfortable, but going though this must be a great way to combat that fear

I'm getting similar eye laser surgery done tomorrow.
I like it.. Thanks Destin.

Highly recommend Lasik. I was 20/150, and 24 hours after I was seeing 20/15 with no pain. It smelled like burnt hair and It hurt during and immediately after once the numbing drops wore off but I took a valium and oxycodone and passed out. I woke up 10 hours later with amazing vision and no pain!
Got mine done at CODET vision in Tijuana, MX. $1998 out the door. Love my 20/20 vision. Couldn’t be happier.

i got the operation done 2 years back.... but i am SO glad i didn't see this video before going for it... would have freaked out!
I went to LASIK md in Vancouver Canada. Best choice ever made. Custom wavefront. Clear perfect day and night  vision right from day after

I did lasik just this october and it has been the best investment ever. Although sometimes I still forget that I dont have glasses anymore. This video reminded me of the exact same feeling my eyes had when I was doing it lol.

Man, lasik changed a lot in how it is done over the 2 years between you and me getting it. I'm glad I waited.

That burning smell was a little dis concerning.

I watched this video after I took an appointment for the surgery and thought that I made a huge mistake.
But now after my surgery..I think I made the right choice..
My Eyesight is super clear now and there wasn't any pain...
If you are intimidated by this video, please don't be and go ahead with this surgery..
It will be worth it.
I'll stick my glasses, thanks.

Hey Destin, just wondering if you've ever had any issues since the surgery? I've read quite a few horror stories which trouble me. People also say that your eyes can get worse after a few years and research on long term effects is very scarce. All in all I don't have enough data to determine whether I should get LASIK or not :/
Welp, I had planned on doing this ,but now I'm scared to death.
How did they do it without creating a flap? My understanding is that they have to create a flap regardless in order to access the cornea.
Had my bladeless LASIK 5 days ago. It was safe and felt almost no pressure on my eyes. Lol I smelled the laser coming on too. Smells like an electric fuse. Haha

I hate jesus

I had PRK surgery done back in May. A very similar process except that they don't create a flap. Total time with laser in eye was no more than 20 seconds. I was on the operating table between 5-10 minutes. A very quick procedure. I could see pretty well right off the table. However, the following 5 days or so after surgery were probably the worst. Vision was hit or miss with a constant irritation like sand in my eyes. I can now see 20/15 for the first time in 24 years. Totally worth it!
i had this done a few months ago, best thing i ever did, now have 20/15 vision

okay, so you've found my OTHER only weakness...eyeballs! ugh. i'm was squirming the whole time watching this one too! can't you find a nice calm video of gastric bypass or amputation or brain exploration? something not so repulsive?!?
:-) really, i'm just jealous. my doc told me i wasn't a candidate for lasik b/c of my astigmatism. :-) stupid toric curvature of my lens!
OMG. I am eating right now and I am just laughing and saying oh my god. I am usually not squeamish but your eyes are pretty sensitive and it is that much more worse while eating.
fuck. that.

Psalms 146:8  The LORD openeth the eyes of the blind: the LORD raiseth them that are bowed down: the LORD loveth the righteous:  I had the same procedure done back in 2005, but my flaps were cut with a shot glass razor-twist-o-matic 3000.  I've absolutely LOVED being able to see, but my eyes have been prone to being more dry since. (nerve loss due to the flap causing delayed tears)
Aw c'mon. "The Lord gives sight to the blind"? Science gives sight to the blind.
I've seen worse things and haven't flinched at the sight of them, but seeing this made me cringe a little.

I got 20-80 and I'm only 18, I think I'll wait at least until I know my vision won't change again until I get LASIK, but now I'm scared after watching this vid
The flap isn't loose permanently, it heals back, your eye is one of the fastest healing parts of your body

I'm so glad that such a wonderfull man can now see again that better!
Love your show! I guess you are happy with what they've done to you!
And thank you so much for sharing the video! Always whanted to check out something like that!

Not to contradict you, but it was very painful for me in the 3 or so hours afterwards. It was like getting a grain of sand stuck under my contacts (both eyes!). At the 5 hour mark now though, things are much better. For those saying "aha! it DOES hurt!", in these first few hours of my vision coming back after 28 years of contacts, I don't believe I'd trade it for the world.

Destin, thanks so much for this. I just had it done a few hours ago, and I have to admit, I was NOT prepared for the "discomfort" of the intralase. "Look up. No, look down" "What do you mean look down, I can't figure out a single reference point to even look towards!". Also, it hurt like hell for 3 hours after. Only just now am I able to start seeing again. But you got the video that I would have loved to have gotten from my doc, really grateful to KNOW what was done to me!

The thing that pissed me off though, is that at a certain point I couldn't see the focal dot anymore, so I didn't quite know where to look, I think I focused on the centre of the swirling red of the laser which I assumed to be the focal point.

haha destin, I didn't know you used to wear glasses... I went the epi-lasik path a week ago, it's a much slower process of healing and visual improvement but no corneal flap. I think intralase and epi-lasik are probably the better/safer options for those wanting to investigate further.
See, this is fascinating. Ingrown Townails, Surgeries, and other stuff medical just creeps me out.  I am the opposite of your wife.

Thanks for the vid. Very informative. 
For completeness, Van Der Waal's force is not a vacuum force. The easiest way to think about it is the molecules in a fluid acting like magnets. Water is a permanent dipole and behaves this way naturally. Some molecules can form temporary polarization (induced dipole) when the charge of nearby molecules force electrons (or charged atoms in some cases) to the far side.

@Protectorr13 No real pain to speak of - they use numbing drops before the procedure.  The flap-cutter vacuum seals itself to your eye and it's a bit uncomfortable but that's all.  Even post-op the eyes don't really hurt.  At most it's  like your contacts have been in too long and your eye is a bit raw.

No need to put you out - the whole thing takes no time at all.  They will give you a Valium before so you're pretty well relaxed by the time they make your cornea smoke.
Just had LASIK done this week - this is a great description of the experience!  (Glad I watched it -after- I had the procedure ;-)

I remember when my stepmother had this done, she had cataracts removed too.
Two weeks later I found her sitting outside one night looking up, and crying. When I asked her what why she was crying, she said, "This is the first time I've seen the stars in 35 years". Then I started crying with her, as we marveled in joy at her renewed sight. Now are house is cleaner than its ever been too.

I remember getting my LASIK done. That smell is intense, it's kind of like a mix of burning hair and burning skin. The craziest part was after the surgery I was walked to another room to heal for a few minutes, and at first all I could see were really blurry blobs, no shapes, just colors. Then over the course of 5 minutes my eyes started to focus to the point that they were at before the surgery, then kept going until everything was crystal clear! Don't be afraid, it's totally worth it!
